intro: Leucanthemum vulgare subsp. atratum, commonly known as the black-eyed Susan, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It features showy yellow ray florets surrounding a central cluster of dark, almost black disc florets, giving it its distinctive appearance. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with upright, branching stems covered in gray-green, hairy leaves. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, often found in meadows, woodland edges, and disturbed sites. Its flowers bloom from late spring to early autumn, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
